item.title: What Is New
Abridged Statement
item.description: My goal is to improve our understanding of the connection between voting, economic outcomes, public opinion, and the media through rigorous research. Before joining NYU, I have worked on projects related to discrimination, inclusive capitalism, and behavioral economics. Most of that work was done at MIT and at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Teaching. As a Data Fellow at NYU, I have advised undergraduate students on research design, tidying data, and interpreting empirical results.

item.title: Contact
item.description: Recent/upcoming opportunities to meet: Provo (July 2018) Boston (Late August 2018) Abu Dhabi (January 2019) Chicago (April 2019) Boston (Mid-July 2019) Washington, D.C. (Late August 2019) Chicago (MPSA, April 2020) Prague (EPSA, June 2020) New York (most of the year)

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Summary of Teaching Experience TA for various political science courses at NYU (listed below). Head Teaching Fellow for David Laibson’s and Andrei Shleifer’s Behavioral Economics course at Harvard. TA for Matt Taddy’s Big Data course at Chicago Booth. Some of my teaching notes and slides are posted on my OSF repository. Current instructional activity: Advising undergraduate students on research design, data manipulation, interpreting and communicating empirical results.

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Current instructional activity: Advising undergraduate students on research design, data manipulation, interpreting and communicating empirical results. Undergraduate politics classes taught at NYU Examining the 2016 Election - Inequality, Populism, and Voting. Data Fellow. Advanced seminar for juniors and seniors in American politics led by Professor Jonathan Nagler. Biology of Politics. Data Fellow. Course taught by Professor Chris Dawes. Introduction to Political Theory. Teaching assistant to Professor Dimitri Landa.

item.title: Research
item.description: Publications Don’t Republicans Tweet Too? Using Twitter to Assess the Consequences of Political Endorsements by Celebrities Perspectives on Politics, 18(1), 144-160. With Vaccari, C., Nagler, J. & Tucker, J. A. item.title: Introduction
item.description: I am a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Politics at NYU. My academic work includes evaluations of the narratives surrounding the 2016 U.S. presidential election, and predictions of economic sentiment around the world with disciplined approaches to model selection inspired by machine learning. In my role as a research associate at the NYU Center for Social Media and Politics I track, with my collaborators, voters’ attitudes using survey data augmented with behavioral outcomes such as respondents’ activity on social media.
